channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Rachel Balkovec, a groundbreaking baseball coach, will become the manager of a team in the Yankees’ minor league system, making her the first woman to lead an affiliated professional baseball squad. https://t.co/HmEAMiiTZm

For the first time, surgeons have successfully transplanted a genetically altered pig’s heart into a patient. The procedure may bring new hope to hundreds of thousands of people with organ failure. https://t.co/UFkJnUHTU5
In a first, a man receives a heart from a genetically altered pig https://t.co/gLavGM2fu2

Rapid at-home Covid tests are inaccessible to blind people as they require complex steps and have no Braille guides. Some apps offer support, but these interactions are difficult, and not everyone who is blind is able to use a smartphone. https://t.co/f9EGgV6vdW

Breaking News: Privately insured Americans can be reimbursed starting Saturday for eight at-home coronavirus tests per person per month under a new plan announced on Monday by the Biden administration. https://t.co/Ze3y0gEx7h

Misinformation about Covid-19 tests — including PCR and at-home tests — has spiked across social media in recent weeks. The burst of misinformation threatens to further stymie public efforts to keep the health crisis under control. https://t.co/3gKByPKSzU https://t.co/cF9XYJWbTl

Breaking News: A man received a new heart from a genetically modified pig, a medical first that offers hope to hundreds of thousands of patients with failing organs. https://t.co/CMQEPN9IL9 https://t.co/wSYwFwmqV9

Clay Aiken, the former “American Idol” contestant, said that he was running for Congress in North Carolina. On his new website, Aiken, 43, referred to himself as a “loud and proud Democrat.” https://t.co/ov8WGN4XNY
Breaking News: Robert Durst, the real estate tycoon who was long suspected in three killings, and found guilty of one of them, is dead at 78. https://t.co/wRM3cox34D
Never miss a meteor shower, eclipse or rocket launch again. https://t.co/J56IdaHRIN https://t.co/kSWu2GobTV
Scientists say a microscopic battle between fungus and bacteria on the skin of hedgehogs provides evidence that antibiotic resistance can occur in nature. https://t.co/Kzk1cidC0d

"I will never ever have another friend like him," John Stamos, who starred alongside Bob Saget in "Full House," said in a tweet. "I love you so much Bobby." https://t.co/AJ6pUaBAff https://t.co/RZbGFaynCf
Mayor Eric Adams said Sunday's deadly fire in the Bronx was likely caused by a space heater. At least 19 people, including nine children, were killed. https://t.co/XA06IZBXO0

Josh Wardle, a software engineer in Brooklyn, knew his partner loved word games and created a guessing game for the two of them called Wordle. Just over two months after releasing it to the rest of the world, the once-a-day game has over 300,000 players. https://t.co/4hXBfIapxX

"I almost got lost because it was so dark."
Residents who survived the deadly fire in the Bronx on Sunday described a quiet morning that suddenly was overtaken by terror and tragedy. https://t.co/23F1OsKuUK
Breaking News: Novak Djokovic won a legal victory in his bid to avoid deportation from Australia and compete for a record 21st Grand Slam tennis title. https://t.co/wMtgtYGDr1
Jumping rope isn’t just for little kids and boxing montages. It's also a portable workout that builds strength, speed, and protects our bodies as we age. https://t.co/Ctf7WXkEcO

"I will never ever have another friend like him," John Stamos, who starred alongside Bob Saget in "Full House," said in a tweet. "I love you so much Bobby." https://t.co/mChbeu83UN https://t.co/ef8A2o3UcS
Breaking News: Bob Saget, the comedian and actor known for his role in “Full House” and as host of “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” has died at 65. https://t.co/d1tf4IM7Zj
Bob Saget, the actor known as Danny Tanner on “Full House” and the host of “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” has died. He was 65. https://t.co/PxNxEKYDdN https://t.co/k5sYJlZ09n

Breaking News: At least 19 people were killed, including 9 children, in a fire at a Bronx apartment building on Sunday. “The numbers are horrific,” Mayor Eric Adams said. Follow live updates here: https://t.co/U7bqiODZNt

"You’re seeing a broken system breaking down even further." A year into President Biden's term, only 41% of his nominees for Senate-confirmed posts have been approved, a new analysis found, the worst rate in decades. https://t.co/1xxJlMwabU

A fire in a Bronx apartment building on Sunday killed at least 19 people, including nine children. A total of 63 people were injured.
“This is going to be one of the worst fires that we have witnessed during modern times,” Mayor Eric Adams said. https://t.co/zHSQITGAtK https://t.co/Cl2pFncv1G

It’s too soon to predict the full impact Omicron could have on deaths and illness across the U.S.
But data in some of the earliest-hit cities is beginning to show what the future could hold. Here's what it shows.
https://t.co/v3mJZ63Gji
A clip of an exasperated Elmo on “Sesame Street” has captivated people online who see a reflection of their own frustrations. https://t.co/WMzoJzeg8Q
Cinnamon rolls are always a good idea. This recipe comes together in under an hour. https://t.co/z23ge02pim https://t.co/JOAhBLcSCh

The number of hospitalized young children infected with the coronavirus rose precipitously last week to the highest levels since the beginning of the pandemic, according to data released on Friday by the CDC. Here's what to know. https://t.co/pLsf0QfqRI https://t.co/ATv7xT3E3K

Luiza Trajano turned a small family store into a retail giant. Parties across the political spectrum have begged her to run for office — seeing in her a rare blend of pragmatism, charisma and smarts. https://t.co/fLdyzoHKBa https://t.co/bDf9lAp4B0

Russian forces now surround Ukraine on three sides — about 100,000 troops, according to Ukrainian and Western officials. See where, and why Western officials fear a military operation could start as soon as this month. https://t.co/pp9cHGz2cs

Yao Pan Ma, an immigrant from China who was left in a coma after a brutal assault in April, died last week. The police called the attack a hate crime, and Ma, 61, had been a ventilator and was hospitalized since the assault occurred in East Harlem. https://t.co/xl8iWqsQBW

Virus cases have hit new highs in the U.S. Hospitalizations topped the height of the Delta wave. Deaths are starting to rise.
If the Omicron variant is less severe overall, it can be hard to understand the trends. Here’s how to think about the data now. https://t.co/GroeWzHhWi

In Opinion
"It’s disgusting that Republicans could not honor the institution they took an oath to protect, or even show up for the cops and other staffers they see every day who were traumatized by Jan. 6," Maureen Dowd writes. https://t.co/8tb6kOT8HP

The James Webb Space Telescope has completed a final, crucial step: unfolding the last section of its golden, hexagonal mirrors. That amounts to it becoming fully deployed, according to NASA. https://t.co/rFaacTdYx2

In Opinion
"The Australian Border Force did what sports bodies are failing to do: say no. If athletes don’t like restrictions imposed on the unvaccinated, they could just get a shot like millions of other people," Lindsay Crouse writes. https://t.co/Ws8u67yADh

New York Times readers are honoring Sidney Poitier by sharing tributes and memories.
Join the conversation: https://t.co/yB5nBP8Dn9 https://t.co/bqpS0DgjGV

“Dear Mom, Received another letter from you today and was happy to hear that everything is okay,” a 22-year-old soldier wrote on Dec. 6, 1945. “As for myself, I’m fine and getting along okay.”
Last month, his letter was finally delivered. https://t.co/h7AzVBjd4H
Amy Schneider has become the first woman in the history of “Jeopardy!” to surpass $1 million in winnings during regular-season play. https://t.co/NpiB2l51Cr
A group of Canadian social media influencers and others flouted Covid-19 rules on a flight to Cancún, Mexico, resulting in airlines leaving many of them without a way home. https://t.co/LwEjVG33sa

In an instant, Sidney Poitier moved America into the age of Black Power, our critic writes. The year, 1967. The movie, “In the Heat of the Night.” It was “the slap heard around the world.” https://t.co/Inv9BzZ8eQ

"Were anyone to ask me who’s the greatest American movie star," @Wesley_Morris writes, "my answer would never change. And it will never change because the answer is easy. The greatest American movie star is Sidney Poitier." https://t.co/YtERPb4Ijf

Citigroup will dismiss unvaccinated employees by the end of the month as it presses on with a vaccine requirement the company announced in October. More than 90% of its 65,000 U.S. employees have complied with the requirement. https://t.co/Xl94a1Pxgo

Pakistan cleared the way for the first woman in its history to become a Supreme Court justice with the nomination of Justice Ayesha Malik to the top court. The move was hailed by lawyers and activists after decades of struggle for greater representation. https://t.co/laBEqD1XTL
On Friday, Amy Schneider became the first woman in the history of “Jeopardy!” to surpass $1 million in winnings during regular-season play. https://t.co/l2ZaeDs22O

Luiza Trajano, who turned a small family store into a Brazilian retail giant, has spoken bluntly about race, inequality and domestic violence.
Now, a company policy limiting its executive training program to Black applicants is drawing praise and outrage. https://t.co/EcF52ebvOZ https://t.co/nco0fcX6vb

Women who received Covid shots had slightly longer menstrual cycles after being vaccinated, a study found, validating anecdotal reports of erratic cycles. But their periods themselves were not prolonged, and bounced back to normal within one or two months. https://t.co/5DR6PofP8U
A Georgia judge sentenced the three men convicted of killing Ahmaud Arbery to life in prison. Only one will be eligible for parole. https://t.co/13OJC0lTAA https://t.co/k9q5ML9ot5

At a time when Hollywood often relegated Black actors to roles as servants, Sidney Poitier was rarely a supporting player. These 11 movies, available to stream, span the 1950s to the ‘90s and highlight what made him popular with white and Black audiences. https://t.co/myzHaL4aeJ
Breaking News: U.S. employers added only 199,000 jobs in December as hiring slowed and the economy stumbled, even before Omicron threatened the labor market. https://t.co/Tp0XMQ6FRh
Children who have recovered from Covid-19 appear to be at significantly increased risk of developing Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes, CDC researchers reported on Friday. https://t.co/tFTcb80MeR

Sidney Poitier made history in 1964 as the first Black performer to win an Oscar in the best-actor category, for the comedy-drama "Lilies of the Field." Watch his acceptance speech here. https://t.co/DwN3EcS2b4
